comments.commentBody: I would like to ponder the relationship between the U.S. and China through the lens of "The Art of War." I am not sure if modern day China comes through too well at first glance. China has hidden burdens that may show it's ugly head if the Chinese government push their people too far. A view of what Sun Tzu wrote may be to say that leaders who force their people could expect calamity.

Unfortunately the diversity of incoming international students is decreasing.

http://oscarloveslife.blogspot.com/2012/01/diversity-of-foreign-students...

India's present economic model is derivative - it does not address the basic needs of its people. Economic systems to work and to enjoy legitimacy have to be aimed at the lower middle bracket of a population and below.

That is the point at which the majority of a people in most countries, and certainly in India, live. Products and services can then be priced to match their purchasing power and collectively, their purchasing power is staggering. The current system fosters conspicuous consumption but ignores the basic needs of Indians - food, clean air, clean water, shelter and clothing.

Wal Mart may or may not be welcome in India. But there is room and a crying need for hundreds of sub-Wal Marts in the country. If I were advising US corporations looking for growth in India, that is where I would direct their attention. That old saw among marketing strategists that you segment a population by their needs and then by their value is the key that unlocks the golden door.

Siddhartha Banerjee
Oxford, Pennsylvania

comments.userDisplayName: Allister Fraser, BS, MS, Brown U., PhS, U of Illinois

Rural Indians suffer from an abject lack of proper medical care primarily because many nurses from Indian cities feign as doctors and give our prescriptions and pills without much knowledge. If people in rural India are getting a chance to get attended by a certified Apollo hospital doctor ( an elite medical institution) , this is certainly a welcome change and the cost is most definitely justified for the quality of care they will be offered.
You can consult a see a doctor in person for a little more money than the 50 rupees. I think it is expensive for what they are offering.

I would be outraged, especially as a parents.  These early moments with your child have been lost and I would definitely sue the hospital for this disgraceful management of this situation.

The better question is why didn't they emulate what Brangelina did by goiong to Africa to have their child. If I were that wealthy and famous, why would I even both coming to any public hospital when I could easily have the childbirth at my mansion with a mid-wife and retain the services of an obstetrician on call? The word "hubris" comes to mind. I would never allow my famous wife to have a child in any NYC hospital, no disrespect. So I now have greater respect for Brangelina because their money went for a worthy cause helping children and the local economy of the country where they had their child. Unfortunately, black people don't think like this, and yes, I am black. My wife would never have wanted to inconvenience other parents or patients by pulling such a stunt. Now if the Jigga compensates all of those parents and others inconvenienced by this stunt for their suffering, then it would be worth it. However, most so-called celebrities of his generation lack humility. $1.3 million would have gone a long way in Acra, Ghana or Niger, or Malawi where Madonna is working her magic - love you material girl.

It is clearly another illustration of the "I am more important than you" mentality that highlights how social class separates the have from the working class - yes, this class does have their own. Why he would want to have his child in filthy New York is beyond me with his income level.

For once, Americans (at that hospital) felt how to be treated as Mexicans in America!

Every where there is first class and second class. Some times prejudice is based on race and some other times its based on wealth.....
701,360 people voted in NH in 2008 for presidential election.

Considering NH has a total of 1.3 million voter out of some 1.5 million total population. This total conservative republican vote count of 204442 is 16 %.. That 16% of the total have come out to vote for these GOP lead by the Mr. private equity high priest of the Mormon Church are immaterial and irrelevant as compared to some 350 million people in this nation. Romney the Mitt essentially has won nothing, and him to represent these republicans that comprise something less then 25% of the total US population will in the end amount to nothing. It is a sorry sight for a nation to elect a president where there is so much apathy, disenfranchised people and some 40 to 50 % that just care.

Romney the Mitt with his some 30 odd mittens will be nightmare for the secret service if he becomes the GOP candidate.

US taxpayers are up in arms with expense of four Obamas in the WH. Just imagine what it will be with some over 30 Romneys and when other high priests of the Mormon Church and all those sister wives come calling.

@al

Can someone tell me why people who hate the President focus of the teleprompter of all things? They’ve been in use for decades and all presidents use them as far as I know. Is it that they so hate well-educated, articulate people that they just cannot resist attacking them in some way?

To say that you prefer the current spectacle reflects poorly on your own intellect, especially since you do refer to it as a spectacle, but I’m not sure you will grasp this nuance of perspective.

To al: I will add to Janet Camp's questioning of you taking offense at the use of the teleprompter. You should listen to President Obama when he is giving one of thi stump speeches. No teleprompter in sight. Still, he is extremely articulate, quick witted, and fully in command. He has a brilliant mind and is fully able to express his points of view without notes. In formal speeches, as you may not know since you may not have given a formal speech, having the text in front keeps the speech on track and on time. All presidents have used them since the tool was available. Before that presidents used a written text and read from it.

Bringing up the "teleprompter" issue just makes you look ridiculous to me and to Janet Camp and perhaps to many other NYTimes readers, although it might play well on a FoxNews blog.

Ordinary people need to experience personal misfortune before accepting a qualified opinion.

How do you label people who cannot/will not change their minds under any circumstance?

The main point of this editorial is exactly on the mark.

Mitt Romney's rivals for the Republican nomination probably don't actually believe it, but they are peddling the line the private equity industry is the unethical bastard child of the otherwise triumphant and eminently just American version of capitalism championed by Republicans from Ronald Reagan on.

But talking up this foolishness will only raise more questions about the power big money has -- and uses with nary a thought of its destructive effects on working people in particular and the USA in general.

In some ways it was inevitable that the greed and callousness that lie at the heart of right-wing "thought" would finally impel Newt Gingrich to loose this genie from the Republicans' bottle of bile.

I must admit that for me it is gratifying to watch these money-grubbing power-hungry selfish twits go after one another in public. Maybe the spectacle will finally wake up all those brainwashed TV watchers who are manipulated year after year with race baiting, hippie bashing, gay bashing, and terrorism inflating idiocy into voting for people who suck their blood while they are sleeping and laugh about it while thinking up the next whopper with which to bamboozle the uniformed.

Good points. This guy also wants to repeal "Obama care" which could really hurt many people who could finally get insurance.
